intro: Cristaria obtusiloba, commonly known as the narrow-leafed broomrape, is a parasitic flowering plant that lacks chlorophyll and relies on host plants for nutrients. It belongs to the Orobanchaceae family and is native to parts of Europe and Asia. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers and has a taproot system that attaches to the roots of its host. It is often found in dry, disturbed soils and can be a challenge for agricultural crops. Its botanical features make it an interesting subject for studies on parasitic plant biology.
